message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The horizontal nystagmus observed during examination further supports the diagnosis. The next best step in management would be reassurance and administration of vestibular suppressants such as meclizine or dimenhydrinate. Antibiotics and high-dose steroids are not indicated in the case of BPPV. MRI of the brain with gadolinium may be considered if there is no improvement in symptoms despite initial management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing benign positional vertigo, which is a common cause of dizziness. The horizontal nystagmus observed during the examination supports this diagnosis. The next best step in management would be reassurance and vestibular suppressants, as the condition often resolves on its own but can be helped with medication to control symptoms. Antibiotics and steroids would not be indicated in this case, and an MRI of the brain with gadolinium would not be necessary without further indications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of vertigo, which is usually caused by an inner ear disorder. The presence of horizontal nystagmus indicates peripheral vestibular dysfunction. MRI with gadolinium is not necessary at this point, as the symptoms are most likely due to benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Treatment options for BPPV include reassurance, vestibular suppressants, and maneuvers like the Epley maneuver to reposition the displaced otoconia in the inner ear. Antibiotics and high dose steroids are not indicated unless there is an evidence of concurrent infection or autoimmune condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The next best step in management is reassurance and vestibular suppressants. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and high dose steroids are not indicated. MRI of the brain with gadolinium may be indicated if neurologic symptoms or signs are present, which are not mentioned in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which can be treated with vestibular suppressants and reassurance. MRI and antibiotics are not indicated for BPPV. High dose steroids are not indicated either and may cause more harm than benefit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), a disorder caused by displacement of small crystals in the inner ear. The next best step would be to offer reassurance and vestibular suppressants, such as meclizine, to relieve her symptoms. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and high dose steroids are not indicated for BPPV. An MRI with gadolinium may be ordered if more serious causes are suspected, such as a cerebrovascular accident or acoustic neuroma, but is not necessary as the patient’s presentation is typical of BPPV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing benign positional vertigo, which can be managed with vestibular suppressants and reassurance. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and high dose steroids are not indicated for this condition. MRI of the brain with gadolinium may be useful to rule out other causes of vertigo, but is not the next best step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the observed horizontal nystagmus indicate benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), a common cause of peripheral vertigo. The next best step is reassurance and vestibular suppressants, which can help relieve symptoms. MRI or antibiotics are not indicated for BPPV. Steroids are not appropriate for this type of vertigo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings are consistent with Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). Reassurance and vestibular suppressants such as meclizine or dimenhydrinate are the best initial management options for BPPV. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and high dose steroids are not indicated for BPPV. MRI of the brain with gadolinium may be considered if there are other concerning neurological symptoms or if there is suspicion for an underlying central cause of vertigo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The next best step in management is reassurance and vestibular suppressants. Options A and B are not indicated in the management of BPPV. MRI of the brain with gadolinium may be considered if central vertigo is suspected.
